metadata.title: Effect of nano-silica on the mechanical properties of acrylic polyurethane coatings

ffect of nano-silica on the mechanical properties of acrylic olyurethane coatings
assoud Malaki a,∗, Yasser Hashemzadeh b, Mehdi Karevan a
Department of Mechanical Engineering, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan, Iran Department of Materials Engineering, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan, Iran
r t i c l e i n f o
rticle history: eceived 23 May 2016 eceived in revised form 6 September 2016 ccepted 7 September 2016
eywords: rosion learcoat ano-composite ano silica utomotive paint
a b s t r a c t
A special focus has recently been made on the enhancement of the mechano-tribological properties of the clearcoats commonly used in several industries such as the automotive manufacturing sectors. However, still further investigations are needed for the better understanding of the behavior of such clearcoats in different working conditions. The purpose of the current research was investigating the erosion resistance, adhesive strength, micro-hardness and weathering stability of the acrylic-based polyurethane nano-composites which were reinforced by precipitated and fumed nano-silica particles. To achieve this, Zeta Sizer, scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analyses were used. Furthermore, a series of experimental tests including the adhesive strength, toughness, micro-hardness and erosion resistance were carried out to measure the mechanical response of the fabricated clearcoats. It was concluded that the nano-silica additives significantly improve the adhesive strength, and highly increase the micro-hardness as well as the erosion resistance. It is also found that the precipitated nano-silica is able to create an inexpensive, hard and tough coatings rendering it very durable against wear, weathering conditions, and, thus, can be potentially employed as a reinforcing filler and as a replacement to the fumed clearcoats that are usually much more expensive than the proposed reinforcement.
© 2016 Published by Elsevier B.V.
. Introduction
Polymer based coatings are widely used in a variety of appliations in order to protect surfaces underneath against impact, cratch, wear, corrosion and weathering conditions, solvents, etc. ne of the most common coatings used as protection against the forementioned issues is polyurethane. Epoxy based coatings are pecific types which are extremely transparent and possess good to xcellent weathering stability, high toughness, and excellent resisance against wear and corrosive chemicals [1,2].
One of the key applications of the acrylic-based polyurethane is ts use in the top clearcoat of automobile body. As a final coating, he top layers are to be as much glossy, transparent and resisant against harsh weathering conditions as possible. Ley et al. 3] studied the optimization of acrylic polyols for two-component ater-based polyurethane top coatings offering an excellent hard-
ess and mechanical strength. Apart from the several downsides
∗ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 912 4424739. E-mail addresses: massoudmalaki@gmail.com, m.malaki@cc.iut.ac.ir
M. Malaki).
ttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.porgcoat.2016.09.012 300-9440/© 2016 Published by Elsevier B.V.
of the polyurethane clearcoats, further investigations are highly required. It is mostly because these clearcoats do not offer enough resistance against impact and wear, as well as appropriate protection against chemical corrosive/erosive substances.
The use of inorganic particles such as Al2O3, TiO2, CaCO3 and SiO2 as reinforcements added to clearcoats has been an interesting topic of a great body of research work, yet the utilization of these fillers has been shown a pressing issue due mainly to the unavoidable challenges mentioned earlier. These particles are however added into a neat polymer and are expected to considerably enhance mechanical, chemical and or even optical properties of the filled materials.
Silica particles are divided into three groups: (1) precipitated silica, (2) fumed silica, and (3) colloidal silica among which the former is synthesized by a wet chemical method. In this process, silica is produced when H2SO4 or HCl is reacted by silicate resulting in a precipitated type of nano-silica. The fumed silica is synthesized thorough the hydrolysis of SiCl4 in the flame of oxygen-hydrogen [4]. The reaction is expressed as follows:
SiCl4 + 2H2 + O2 → SiO2 + 4HCl

A high quality clearcoat needs to be as glossy as possible and ence light scattering parameter (Pscat) must be known. Accord-
ng to the Rayleigh’s equation expressed by Eq. (1), the refractive ndices of the nano-particles should be equal to those of the poly-
eric matrix; moreover, the particle size should not exceed the ight wavelength [5].
scat = 22 4P0 ( n′ − n ) ( V2/ 4 ) (1)
here Pscat is the light scattering parameter, P0 and are the light ower and the light wavelength, respectively, and V are respecively the portion and the size of suspended particles, and n and n′ re the refractive indices of the polymer matrix and the suspended articles, respectively.
Mixing and the degree of homogeneity are of high imporance in the reinforced polymer composites. Lack of an effective
ixing/dispersion, a myriad of defects and insufficient interfaces reated between the reinforcing particles and the matrix are xpected. The aforesaid drawbacks, unfavorably, result in a sigificant reduction in the overall mechanical properties of the abricated clear coatings. Extensive work has been reported by Zhou et al. [6,7] in respect f the acrylic and polyester based polyurethane/colloidal nanoilica coatings. It is indicated that the preparation route and ifferent silane couple agents leave underlying significant effect n redispersibility as well as the mechanical performance of the learcoats. Arena et al. [8] studied the solid particle erosion and he viscoelastic properties of thermoplastic polyurethanes by the tudy of the morphological, tribological, viscoelastic response of lear coatings. It was shown that thermoplastic polyurethane disipates the impact energy of the erodent materials. Petrović et al. 9] investigated the structure and properties of polyurethane-silica anocomposites. Maganty [10] et al. found that the mechanial properties of polyurethane composite coatings are improved pon the addition of nano-silica. The mar resistance of automoive clearcoats was experimentally studied by Scrinzi et al. [11]. he results indicate that both mar resistance and hardness improve hen nano-silica particles are added to the neat polymer. Eslami t al. [5] studied the optical properties of the transparent acrylic ased polyurethane nano-silica composite coatings by the turbidity nd UV–vis absorption tests. Kotnarowska et al. [12] examined the ear resistance of epoxy-polyurethane coating modified by TiO2. It as indicated that the erosion resistance was remarkably improved
y the addition of TiO2 nanofiller. For the fabrication of turbine blades, polyurethane coatings rein-
orced by boron carbide (B4C) or silicon carbide (SiC) nanoparticles n a 16Cr-5Ni martensitic stainless steel substrate was examined y Syamsundar et al. [13]. It is indicated that the samples reinorced by the B4C nanoparticles outperform those filled with the iC nanoparticles. The improvement observed was correlated to he higher hardness of the B4C nanoparticles than that of SiC llers. The effect of non-polar nano-silica particles on the elecrochemical properties of 2-pack polyurethane matrix was studied y Mills et al. [14]. They represent that the abrasion resistance is nhanced by higher curing temperatures or the addition of nanoilica particles. The use of precipitated silica with silanol groups as n inorganic chain extender in polyurethane was reported by Chen t al. [15]. Das et al. [16] studied the effect of nano-silica additives on he physicochemical, morphological and curing characteristics of ransesterified castor oil based polyurethane coatings. Eslami et al. 5] examined the optical property of the nano-silica/polyurethane learcoats. According to their turbidity results, the addition of nanoilica below 2 wt% of powder will not result in a decrease in the
egree of the transparency. They concluded that the gloss of such
nano-silica/polyurethane clearcoats remained unchanged. Howver, upon the addition of further amount of nano-silica, the gloss evel reduced. For example, 1.8% and 23% reductions in the gloss
level were reported respectively for the 4 wt% and 6 wt% of the precipitated nano-silica/polyurethane clearcoats. Accordingly, 4.3% and 5.3% reductions were respectively observed for the fumed type of nano-silica/polyurethane clearcoats.
In the present work, two types of precipitated and fumed nanosilicas are added to an acrylic-based polyurethane clear coating to examine possible improvement in mechanical, optical and tribological properties. The adhesion, microhardness, and erosion resistance behavior of clearcoats are discussed and examined. The effect of addition of fumed and precipitated nano-silica reinforcements are thoroughly compared and discussed.
2. Experiments
2.1. Materials
Two types of nano-silica were used as fillers in the reinforcing process of the polyurethane clearcoats. Table 1 shows the material properties of the fillers used in this study.
The fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of the fumed and precipitated nano-silica particles is shown in Fig. 1. Surface hydroxyl groups are shown in both fumed and precipitated nanosilicas. Silanol group density of the fumed nano-silica particle is rather lower than that of precipitated samples which is shown in Fig. 1. Fig. 2 represents the X-ray diffractions that support the presence of the amorphous structure of the two types of nano-silica particles. Fig. 3 shows a representative TEM image of the fumed nano-silica particles. The image clearly supports the expected geometry and average dimensions of the reinforcements being at a nano-size level. Moreover, the image represents aggregated and agglomerated fillers already present in the synthesized nano-fillers. The TEM image was recorded by a TEM Zeiss EM-10C instrument to examine the structure by passing electrons through the samples.
The polyurethane used in this research consists of two parts, an acrylic-based polyol resin solved in a solution of butyl acetate/xylene and a hardener from poly isocyanate aliphatic group

both parts are provided by Bayer Co. from Germany). The characeristics of these materials are given in Table 2. Ester butyl glycol cetate was used as a solvent to prepare the silica sol and acrylicased polyol resin. Xylene was used as a dilution solvent. Both Ester utyl glycol acetate and Xylene were supplied by BASF Co.
As St-37 carbon steel is typically used in most industrial parts, .g. car body, chemical reservoirs, fuel tanks, offshore and marine tructures, St 37 was used as the substrate for the study of the oating-substrate properties. The chemical composition of this teel consists of C: 0.19%, Si: 0.23%, Mn: 0.87%, Si: 0.017%, Cr: 0.03%, o < 0.01%, Ni: 0.01%, Cu < 0.01%, V < 0.01%.
.2. Nano coatings synthesis
A nano-composite polyurethane clearcoat/nano-silica was prouced according to the following steps: first, 2 and 4 wt% of ano-silica powder (fumed or precipitated) were mixed with butyl lycol acetate solvent; the solution was further mixed by a magetic mixer at 1500 rpm giving the solution an appropriate time for he formation of the silica sol. This process follows the equation iven below:
= A A + B (2)
here F, A, and B are the nano-silica weight fraction, the mass of
ano-silica powder and the solvent, respectively.
Second, silica sol (1, 2, 4 and 6 wt% of nano-silica depending on he solid percent of resin) was added to the acrylic polyol resin olvent and then the product was vigorously homogenized by a
disc-type mixer at 3000 rpm. Eq. (3) is used to calculate the weight percent of nano-silica in the resin composite.
W = ws × ps ws × ps + wr × pr
(3)
where W is the weight percent of nano-silica in the resin composite. ws, ps, wr, and pr are the sol weight, the solid percent of sol, resin weight, and the solid percent of resin, respectively.
Finally, a given weight of the curing agent part was added to the compound fabricated in the previous step. The portion of NCO/OH is to be about 1.2. The viscosity was controlled by xylene dilution solvent dictated by the spray process. This solution was used as the clearcoat through the spray process. The steel substrate was polished by an emery cloth (meshed 100), cleaned by water and then dried at the ambient temperature.
For this work, the 1, 2, 4 and 6 wt% of precipitated nano-silica samples were represented as PS1, PS2, PS4 and PS6, respectively, for the sake of simplicity. Accordingly, in the case of 1, 2, 4 and 6 wt% of fumed nano-silica, FS1, FS2, FS4 and FS6 were respectively used.
The coating was performed by an air spray. The specimens were then exposed to air at the room temperature for 24 h. The samples were then placed in an oven for 48 h at 50 ◦C.
2.3. Characterization
The changes in the microstructural and topography of the eroded surface of the specimens were studied using the SEM (Philips XL30 Series). The distribution of nano-silica particles in the acrylic polyol resin matrix was examined by a Zeta Sizer Nano-ZS analyzer (Malvern Co., USA) in accordance with the ISO13320. The

ig. 4. Distribution of fumed and precipitated nano-silica particles in the resin atrix.
icro-hardness experiments were conducted based on the ASTM -1474 [17]. A Buehler micro-hardness tester with a load of 10 g,
he loading time of 10 s and the magnification of 500 was used. The dhesion strength was evaluated by the pull-off test according to he ASTM D-4541 [18]. Under the testing conditions, the adhesive nd cohesive fracture of the coated materials was expected [19]. he adhesive failure refers to the failure occurred at the interfaces etween the coating layer and the substrate, whereas the cohesive ype occurs within the coating material itself.
The erosion test was performed according to the ASTM D-968 20]. Two separate test procedures are set forth in this standard. The rst method (A) stipulates that the silicon sand particles are used s erosive material, while in the second one (B) the SiC particles re used as the erosive substance. The former approach (A) being onsidered as more frequent method was used in the present study.
. Results and discussion
.1. Redispersibility
According to the TEM result, it is clearly shown that the size f synthesized reinforcements falls into a nano-size level. Fig. 4 hows the redispersibility in the case of the fumed and precipitated ano-silica fillers within the resin matrix. As shown in Fig. 4, the ano-silica distribution quality in the case of 2 and 4 coatings wt% is omparable to that of the raw nano-silica powder. This observation uggests that the agglomeration is negligible at low nano-filler wt% nd thus a uniform distribution is expected to be achieved. This bservation could be attributed to the high polarization of silanol roups on the nano-silica surfaces and the polarity of acrylic polyol esin [21]. The findings corroborate the existence of a high chemical ompatibility between these two components exists.
At the higher contents of nano-silica (∼6 wt%), agglomeration appears to dominate the overall properties. The main reason for this observation is the creation of the hydrogen bonds among the adjacent silanol groups, the increase in the particles size, and the shift in the distribution peak toward the higher values.
For the lower density of surface silanol groups, the fumed nanosilica has smaller particle size than the precipitated nano-silica. Thus, it is concluded that there are two forces dominating the redispersibility performance: (I) the attractive forces between the surface silanol groups of the nano-silica and the polar groups of the acrylic resin including hydroxyl, carbonyl, etc. and (II) the attractive forces among the surface silanol groups of the neighboring nanosilicas. The former leads to the dispersion and the later contributes to the formation of agglomeration. At a lower wt%, the force “I” is dominant while by increasing weight fractions and decreasing distances between the particles, the later force (force II) can be dominant.
3.2. Adhesion strength
The adhesion strength is of crucial importance in the fabrication of the filled clearcoat nanocomposites [22]. It is well documented that the extent of adhesion at the interface of the coating material and the substrate significantly governs the mechanical, tribological and corrosion properties of the coated substances. Figs. 5 and 6 shows the results of the pull-off tests concerning the fumed and precipitated nano-silica clearcoats, respectively.
As is shown, when nano-silica weight fraction (either fumed or precipitated) increases, the adhesion strength increases. For instance, a 40% improvement in the adhesion strength is well observed followed by the addition of 4–6 wt% nano-silica. Fig. 7 represents that a cohesive failure occurs in the samples supporting the presence of a strong bonding strength created between the clearcoat and the substrate used.
It is noteworthy that upon the addition of nano-silica content, not only the adhesion strength is enhanced but also the cohesion strength significantly increases as well. Such effects are thought to be greatly controlled by the precipitated type of nano-silicas.
The adhesion strength increases as the network density of the clearcoat increases. The results show that the addition of nanofillers promotes the network density of polymer chains into the

ig. 6. Pull-off strength results for the acrylic-polyurethane samples with different evels of precipitated nano-silica according to ASTM D4541-02.
atrix. For example, the hydrogen bonding is formed between the ydroxyl groups of the nano-particles and the carbonyl groups of he polyurethane. Consequently, it is thought that a network with a reater degree of crosslink is created, and,thus, the network density f such a network is increased [23]. The clearcoat static modulus mproves when the nano-silica content increases. It is suggested hat the nano-silica static modulus is relatively high. It is clear that his stiffness contributes to the Young’s modulus of the composte according to the simple rule of mixtures (ROM). The trend of he observed findings can also be attributed to the presence of a hird region, the interphase, generated at the interface of the nanoilica-polymer. This phase has frequently been reported to have a reater stiffness than the polymer phase. It is noteworthy that the nterphase is developed when a perfect interfacial surface exists at he interface of the nano-silica and neat polymer matrix [24]. It has een shown that the creation of this region is strongly affected by he extent of the polymer chain immobilization at regions around he surface of the fillers [24,25]. Since at a nano-size level, the speific surface of nanofillers dramatically increases, it has frequently een reported that the interphase alter the performance of polyers reinforced with nanofillers at a macro-size level [26]. It has
een shown that the increase in the density of the polymer chain is key factor contributing to the enhancement in elastic properties s a result of the mechanical interlock between the polymer chains nd the adjacent surface [27].
ig. 7. Pull off strength measures as per ASTM D 4541-02 for acrylic-polyurethane sampl
Furthermore, the chain immobilization of the substrate is expected to enhance both the adhesion strength (between the clearcoat and the substrate) and clearcoat cohesion strength due to the tethering of polymer chains at the surface. One factor that can also corroborate the findings is the presence of a good dispersion and the distribution of the reinforcements in the polymer matrix, which has been shown to enhance the extent of the load transfer at the reinforcement-polymer interface and thus the eventual strength of the composite. Besides this, the existence of small but numerous pinning sites has been shown to hinder the crack propagation and growth [28].
3.3. Microhardness
Figs. 8 and 9 shows the microhardness values with respect to the fumed and precipitated nano-silica/polyurethane clearcoats. The increase in nano-silica contents leads to an increase in the hardness behavior of the clearcoats. For the clearcoats including 2, 4, and 6 wt% of the fumed nano-silica particles, ∼40%, 78%, and 100% increase in the microhardness values are respectively observed. Also, when the same contents are concerned, 22%, 56%, and 100% improvement in the hardness is observed in the case of the precipitated nano-silica/polyurethane clearcoats, respectively. As shown
of the nan-silica particles is more pronounced than that observed in the case of the lower weight fractions. It can also be concluded that the increase in the hardness in the case of the fumed nano-
es with different types of nano-silica reinforcements: (A): PU, (B) FS4 and (C) PS4.

ilica/polyurethane clearcoats is higher than that represented by he samples fabricated through the precipitated technique. The bserved variation in the hardness results can be correlated to the etter level of the distribution and dispersion of nano-silica paricles in the fumed nano-silica/polyurethane clearcoats than the ispersion quality introduced in the precipitated samples.
It has been widely reported that the hardness performance is ffected by the degree of crosslink, network density and polymer odule [29]. The following equations represent the hardness value redicted as a function of the inherent properties of the polymer ano-composites to be known as the Kohlstedt (Eq. (3)) and the arsh (Eq.(4)), respectively [30]. B = [ 0.07 + 0.6 ln ( E/ )] (3) B = 2/3 [ 1 + ln ( E/3 (1 − ) )] (4)
here E, and are the Young’s modulus, yield stress, and poison’s ratio, respectively. As indicated by Eqs. (3) and (4), the effect f the yield stress and the elastic modulus dominates the evenual hardness values. Dasari et al. [31] showed the yield stress ncreases when nano-silica particles are added to a polymer matrix. ccording to Friedrich et al. [32], upon the addition of nan-particles, oth hardness and polymer module increase. In other words, the ard and stiff nature of nano-fillers give rise to the stiffness of the ompound manifested through the increase in the strength of the atrix against a given external load and deformation.
.4. Erosion
The erosion resistance enhancement by the addition of nanoilica particles is examined and discussed. Results shown in Fig. 10 learly display the increase in the contents of nano-silica particuates leads to a considerable increase in the erosion resistance. For , 4, and 6 wt% of the fumed nano-silica particles, 14%, 26% and 29% nhancement in the erosion resistance is respectively observed. urthermore, in the cases of the same weight fraction, when the recipitated samples are taken into consideration, 11%, 21%, and 9% enhancement is observed respectively.
The representative SEM images of the eroded surfaces are shown n Figs. 11 and 12. The surfaces with a higher nano-silica content how a higher resilience against the surface crackings and suggest ar better surface finish. The presence of the nano silica particles mprove the tribological properties, which in turn protects the surace against harsh weathering conditions [33]. The eroded surfaces f the neat PU samples, having no nano-silica content, appear to be
very rough and contain numerous cracks spread out the examined surfaces. Fig. 13 demonstrates the surface characteristics observed under the higher magnifications (400×).
In the case of the neat PU samples, numerous local plastic deformation sites on the eroded surfaces are seen and thus wear behavior appears to be ductile. Ploughing and surface fatigue seem to be the dominating mechanism represented by the fabricated samples. It is also noted that ploughing has been frequently reported as an effective process in the generation of wear debris peeled off polymer nanocomposites [34,35]. In the case of the nano-silica reinforced samples, however, no trace of surface cracking is observed and local deformations are substantially diminished. Ploughing and surface fatigue are the dominant wear mechanisms in the erosion examination of the nano-silica polyurethane clearcoats. As emphasized earlier, the samples reinforced with the nano-silica particles show a greater resilience against wear than the neat polymer. This verifies that the addition of the nano-silica particles effectively prolong the lifetime of the nanocomposites (see Fig. 14). The erosion mechanism can be thought of the steps as follows: the regions of the composite matrix are cut off and eroded by the high-velocity abrasive materials of sharp edges or angles; however, whilst the matrix is eroded, the nano-silica particles are taken away very slowly due to their remarkable hardness. As the matrix layer at the top surface of the nano-silica is abraded, the particles are gradually exposed to the abrasives. The nano-silica particles subjected to the abrasives are protruded out of the matrix surface and protect the matrix/clearcoat against any further erosion. It should be mentioned that this protection is in nano-metric scale and thus a uniform and homogenous distribution of fillers can effectively and efficiently enhance this performance of the clearcoats. The microcracks are then nucleated around the nano-silica particles (at the interfaces) and start propagating into the polymer matrix whilst the erosion/surface fatigue develops. The nano-silica particles are then removed after the surface cracks grow to a specific size.
The reasons explaining the increasing trends observed in the erosion behavior of the samples are briefly given below.
The clearcoat Young’s modulus and hardness have a significant effect on the erosion behavior of the clearcoats. As discussed earlier, the addition of the fumed and precipitated nano-silicas increases the clearcoat hardness. The coatings with greater hardness and modulus have extreme resistance against the plastic deformation. As a result, the fumed nano-silica polyurethane clearcoats having greater hardness than the precipitated nano-silica polyurethane
aving
c w
s r a r n s
learcoats are more durable against harsh weathering conditions, ear and erosion.
The silanol groups make the surface of nano-silica particles o compatible with the polymer matrix and thus the interfaces emains almost defect free. Consequently, such an interface with n appropriate chemical affinity between the polymer and the einforcements acts as an effective obstacle and prevents crack ucleation and growth as is well elaborated in several previous tudies [36,37].
different contents of precipitated nano-silica. A: PU, B: PS2, C: PS4, D: PS6.
4. Conclusions
The current work represents the erosion resistance of acrylicbased polyurethane clearcoats reinforced by the nano-silica powders. It is found that at lower nano-silica concentration, the particle distribution is comparable to that representing by the raw powders. However, by increasing the nano SiO2 wt%, the process is gradually governed by the agglomeration. It is specified that an increase in the nano SiO2 content leads to the enhancement in the adhesion strength. It is indicated that the cohesion strength is
for the
i c s m t f 6 e c l s f m f r s
A
c
mproved more pronounced in the case of precipitated nano-silica learcoats. An increase following a linear fashion in the adhesion trength of clearcoats filled with 1–4 wt% of SiO2 is displayed. The icro-hardness of the clearcoats linearly increases irrespective of he type of fillers. A 100% increase is observed in the case of the umed and precipitated type when the clearcoat is reinforced with
wt% of fillers. It is also understood that the nano-silica particles nable an effective improvement in the erosion resistance of the learcoats. The results show the fumed type of nan-silica offers a ower thickness loss leading to a better erosion resistance of the amples concerned. The SEM results reveal ploughing and surace fatigue as the main erosion mechanism in all samples. The
icro-cracks and sever plastic deformation are seen at the top surace of the pure samples while no micro cracks are evident in the einforced samples. Also, the plastic deformation of the reinforced urfaces is not as severe as that revealed by the neat samples.

metadata.abstractText: A special focus has recently been made on the enhancement of the mechano-tribological properties of the clearcoats commonly used in several industries such as the automotive manufacturing sectors. However, still further investigations are needed for the better understanding of the behavior of such clearcoats in different working conditions. The purpose of the current research was investigating the erosion resistance, adhesive strength, micro-hardness and weathering stability of the acrylic-based polyurethane nano-composites which were reinforced by precipitated and fumed nano-silica particles. To achieve this, Zeta Sizer, scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analyses were used. Furthermore, a series of experimental tests including the adhesive strength, toughness, micro-hardness and erosion resistance were carried out to measure the mechanical response of the fabricated clearcoats. It was concluded that the nano-silica additives significantly improve the adhesive strength, and highly increase the micro-hardness as well as the erosion resistance. It is also found that the precipitated nano-silica is able to create an inexpensive, hard and tough coatings rendering it very durable against wear, weathering conditions, and, thus, can be potentially employed as a reinforcing filler and as a replacement to the fumed clearcoats that are usually much more expensive than the proposed reinforcement. © 2016 Published by Elsevier B.V.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
